page.title: 01LANDSCAPE
page.content: The area to the south of the River Usk is sub-divided again by a ridge, at the top of which is the village of Christchurch. Prominent in the village is Holy Trinity Church, parts of which date from the 12th century. Between the ridge and the River Usk the land is used mainly for farming whereas the majority of the land to the south of the ridge is residential with two large council built estates at St.Julians and Ringland. Road communications are playing an important part in the development of this part of the area with the M4 and A449 linking us with the Midlands, London and West Wales. Two hotels, The Ladbroke Mercury and The Celtic Manor have been developed to cater for conferences and trade shows, taking full advantage of their closeness to these major trunk roads.
